docs.abstract: Gas explosion blasts through coal mine in Shaanxi Province in central China, leaving more than 160 miners missing in what may be one of country's worst coal mine accidents in recent years; country's coal mines are often small, poorly equipped and poorly ventilated; owners have been profiting from China's strong demand for energy; work safety officials acknowledge that hunger for profit and tax revenues among mine owners and local governments often outweighs safety concerns; photo; map (M)

headline.main: 166 Still Missing From China Mine Blast

docs.snippet: A gas explosion blasted through a coal mine in central China in what may be the country's worst coal mine accident in recent years.
docs.lead_paragraph: A gas explosion blasted through a coal mine in central China on Sunday, leaving more than 160 miners missing in what may be one of the country's worst coal mine accidents in recent years. The explosion occurred at 7 a.m. in the Chenjiashan Coal Mine, a state-owned mine in Shaanxi Province, said the official New China News Agency. Black smoke soon poured from the mine's ventilation pipes, said reports on the Web site of the Communist Party's official newspaper, The People's Daily, an indication that many miners could have died of gas poisoning.

docs.abstract: Beijing government procurement office cancels deal to purchase 29.25 million yuan ($3.5 million) worth of Microsoft Windows and Office software after science ministry official complains that local governments are not buying enough Chinese-developed software (S)

headline.main: Technology Briefing | Software: Beijing Cancels Microsoft Order

docs.snippet: Microsoft lost an order from the city of Beijing after a science ministry official complained that local governments were not buying enough Chinese-developed software. Beijing's government procurement office changed its mind about buying 29.25 millio
docs.lead_paragraph: Microsoft lost an order from the city of Beijing after a science ministry official complained that local governments were not buying enough Chinese-developed software. Beijing's government procurement office changed its mind about buying 29.25 million yuan ($3.5 million) worth of Microsoft Windows and Office software on Nov. 27, 10 days after awarding the contract, according to a statement yesterday on its Web site. The decision underscores the challenge Microsoft, whose Windows software runs almost 95 percent of the world's personal computers, faces in building a profitable business in China. Besides competition from the local industry, which the government wants to promote, Microsoft must also cope with widespread piracy of its products. Microsoft officials in Beijing were not immediately available to comment.

docs.abstract: George Vecsey Sports of The Times column discusses increasing importance of legacy of Olympic Games facilities, which is prompting NYC2012 to greatly consider future of arenas that would be built to host 2012 Olympics in New York City; photo (M)

headline.main: Trying Not To Let Games Go to Waste

docs.snippet: In Beijing, the prudent organizers for the 2008 Summer Games are translating the phrase "white elephant" into Mandarin, so they can avoid vacant buildings on the morning after.
docs.lead_paragraph: THERE is nothing emptier than an Olympic arena the day after the flame is extinguished. In the forlorn silence, you can hear the rust forming. This is a serious issue in my neck of the woods. Some lucky, or perhaps unlucky, host in London, Madrid, Moscow, New York or Paris will have to arrange for tae kwon do palaces and team handball temples -- plus have a clue what to do with the buildings after the cheering stops.

docs.abstract: All 44 North Koreans who forced their way into Canadian Embassy in Beijing two months ago have left for undisclosed third country after weeks of diplomacy (S)

headline.main: World Briefing | Asia: China: North Korean Refugees Leave Embassy

docs.snippet: All 44 North Koreans who forced their way into the Canadian Embassy in Beijing two months ago have left for an undisclosed third country after weeks of diplomacy, officials said. The asylum seekers, one of the largest groups ever to enter a diplomati
docs.lead_paragraph: All 44 North Koreans who forced their way into the Canadian Embassy in Beijing two months ago have left for an undisclosed third country after weeks of diplomacy, officials said. The asylum seekers, one of the largest groups ever to enter a diplomatic compound in the Chinese capital, had been holed up inside the embassy since Sept. 29.

docs.abstract: Real estate developer Zhang Yuchen copied 17th-century French chateau in suburban Beijing, hoping to attract China's new rich to rent its rooms and buy homes amid equestrian trails and golf course; 800 peasants who once grew wheat there have lost their land under new rules that allow elite to acquire trappings of America in age of robber barons; photos (M)

headline.main: China's Elite Learn to Flaunt It While the New Landless Weep

docs.snippet: In a generation, a rough-and-tumble form of capitalism is eclipsing the remnants of socialism in China.
docs.lead_paragraph: Chateau Zhang Laffitte is no ordinary imitation. It is the oriental twin of Château Maisons-Laffitte, the French architect François Mansart's 1650 landmark on the Seine. Its symmetrical facade and soaring slate roof were crafted using the historic blueprints, 10,000 photographs and the same white Chantilly stone. Yet its Chinese proprietor, a Beijing real estate developer named Zhang Yuchen, wanted more. He added a manicured sculpture garden and two wings, copying the palace at Fontainebleau. He even dug a deep, broad moat, though uniformed guards and a spiked fence also defend the castle.
